author: By Gina Cherelus
title: What a $50 Million Donation Did for One H.B.C.U.
description: At Prairie View A&M, one of the historically Black colleges and universities where MacKenzie Scott donated millions, the mood is cautious optimism.
content: PRAIRIE VIEW, Texas — In-person learning resumed at Prairie View A&M University at the end of August, and the campus was soon buzzing with familiar sounds and sights: freshmen laughing in the dining hall, students walking across the sprawling yard in between classes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Talya Minsberg
title: TikTok’s running hero, Mrs. Space Cadet, competes in her first marathon.
description: Thousands have followed along as Erin Azar, a self-described “slightly overweight person who drinks too much beer,” trained for the marathon.
content: Erin Azar, known as Mrs. Space Cadet on TikTok, began documenting her runs two years ago. She invited followers to join her, “a slightly overweight person who drinks too much beer,” as she trained for a marathon. But she didn’t anticipate that millions would respond.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kevin Draper
title: Here’s how the full U.F.C. 268 Usman vs. Covington 2 pay-per-view card played out.
description: Thirteen fights lead up to Kamaru Usman vs. Colby Covington.
content: Here are the full results from the U.F.C. 268 card:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Futterman
title: Shalane Flanagan completes her quest: six marathons in six weeks.
description: With all six of the world’s major marathons packed into as many weeks this fall because of the pandemic, Flanagan saw an opportunity to do something extraordinary: run them all.
content: It’s not uncommon for elite runners to take as many as six weeks off from running after a grueling marathon.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Angel Hsu
title: Don’t Be So Quick to Doubt China’s Climate Change Dedication
description: President Biden was among those expressing disappointment over China’s lack of commitment to climate change.
content: “Disappointing.” “A shadow on the global climate effort.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Cataneo
title: Antarctica Was Once a Land of Fire and Not Ice
description: Charcoal recovered from a dig near the southern continent shows that the region wasn’t spared from the era scientists call a “super fire world.”
content: Imagine the forests of Chilean Patagonia: wet and cold, dense with monkey puzzle trees and other hardy conifers. Now imagine it with dinosaurs walking around. And on fire.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vimal Patel and Sophie Kasakove
title: What to Know About the Houston Astroworld Tragedy
description: Eight people were killed at a Travis Scott concert in Houston. Investigators said a crowd surged toward the stage, but the cause remains unknown.
content: At least eight people were killed and dozens more were injured at a concert in Houston after a large crowd began pushing toward the front of the stage during a performance by the hometown rapper Travis Scott.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sabrina Imbler
title: The Biden administration is ‘prepared to defend’ the vaccine rules for big employers, the surgeon general says.
description: The administration last week set Jan. 4 as the deadline for companies with 100 or more employees to mandate Covid vaccinations or implement weekly testing of workers.
content: The Biden administration is “prepared to defend” sweeping new coronavirus vaccine rules for large companies amid new legal challenges, Dr. Vivek Murthy, the surgeon general, said on Sunday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jamie Lauren Keiles, Jack D'Isidoro, Aaron Esposito, John Woo and Dan Powell
title: The Sunday Read: ‘I Fell in Love With Motorcycles. But Could I Ever Love Sturgis?’
description: A New Yorker who started riding during the pandemic travels to the heart of biker culture.
content: Like many other Americans, Jamie Lauren Keiles, the author of this week’s Sunday Read, bought their first motorcycle during the coronavirus pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: In Rural Areas, Prospects Sink for Democrats
description: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, November 7, 2021.
content: “It’s not sustainable for our party to continue to tank in small-town America. We’ve got a branding problem as Democrats in way too many parts of our country.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Heather Murphy
title: International travelers eagerly await reunions with their loved ones as the U.S. travel changes near.
description: On Monday, travelers from many other countries who are fully vaccinated against the coronavirus will be allowed to enter the United States.
content: Across the United States Monday, airports expect to be filled with people reuniting with significant others, parents and friends from the 33 countries that have been prohibited from traveling directly to the United States for more than a year and half.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Morgan Campbell
title: A thin crowd takes in four fights that couldn’t be seen on TV.
description: But the arena was expected to be full for the main event.
content: The preliminary card for the Canelo Álvarez-Caleb Plant fight unfolded in Las Vegas at a three-quarters-empty MGM Grand Garden Arena, which seats more than 17,000 people for boxing events.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dave Itzkoff
title: ‘Saturday Night Live’ Introduces a New Donald Trump
description: James Austin Johnson took on the role of Trump in an episode that also featured appearances by Dionne Warwick and Tracy Morgan. Kieran Culkin of “Succession” was the host.
content: The last time Cecily Strong played the Fox News host Jeanine Pirro on “Saturday Night Live,” it seemed like she might be saying goodbye to her longtime TV home. (She did, after all, end the segment by singing “My Way” and dousing herself in a giant box of wine.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mihir Zaveri
title: New York City Marathon Returns With Fanfare and Optimism
description: The marathon returned as a smaller event after it was canceled last year because of the pandemic, bringing a feeling of collective hope to New York City.
content: The runners gathered in early morning darkness on Staten Island. They ran past confetti cannons in Brooklyn and a heavy metal band in Queens. And after being cheered in the South Bronx, they raced down through Manhattan and ended in Central Park, where volunteers welcomed them with medals and ponchos and supporters clapped from grandstands.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Remy Tumin
title: Infrastructure, Glasgow, New York City Marathon: Your Weekend Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know about the week’s top stories.
content: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra E. Petri
title: A ‘Bachelorette’ star says of her first marathon: It’s just about ‘putting yourself out there.’
description: Tayshia Adams will run the race with her fiancé Zac Clark, who she became engaged to on season 16 of the show.
content: Tayshia Adams, a co-host and previous star of “The Bachelorette,” was among the runners waiting for the Staten Island Ferry to shuttle them to the starting line of the New York City Marathon.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amelia Nierenberg
title: Your Monday Briefing
description: China’s new official history.
content: China’s top leader will most likely take center stage in a new official summation of Communist Party history. The document is likely to exalt Xi, 68, as a peer of Mao Zedong and Deng Xiaoping before his expected re-election at a party congress late next year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ken Belson
title: Marcel Hug and Madison de Rozario Win N.Y.C. Marathon Wheelchair Races
description: Hug, a four-time champion, dominated the men’s division, while de Rozario won her first women’s title, pulling away in the second half of the race.
content: Marcel Hug of Switzerland, known as the Silver Bullet, continued his stellar year by winning the New York City Marathon men’s wheelchair race on Sunday for the fourth time. Madison de Rozario of Australia won her first women’s wheelchair title.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emmanuel Morgan
title: A U.F.C. Champion’s Title Is Not Enough. He Wants to Fight a Boxer Next.
description: Kamaru Usman, the U.F.C.’s top pound-for-pound fighter, is trying to generate buzz for a fight with the boxing champion Saúl Álvarez. It’s not likely to work.
content: Kamaru Usman scrunched his face in a playful manner and tilted his head. He had just defended his Ultimate Fighting Championship welterweight title in a five-round brawl with Colby Covington at Madison Square Garden at U.F.C. 268.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Van Syckle
title: ‘Once the Race Starts, You’re Part of That Race’
description: A New York Times special section captures the history of the New York City Marathon in photographs. We spoke to four photographers who have covered the course for decades.
content: The New York City Marathon, first held in 1970 with 127 runners in Central Park, celebrates its 50th running this year — and an expected 30,000 people will be on the starting line. Ten Times photographers will be on site to cover the race, an increase from the one who shot the event in 1970. Photo editors recently dug through The Times’s archives and collected images from the last five decades for a recent special section that chronicles the race’s history in pictures. In interviews, four Times photographers who have documented the race for many years shared their experiences on the ground. They discussed the early days, bumping along on the press truck and how they get their shots. Their interviews have been edited and condensed for clarity.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jessica Testa
title: Jil Sander Ski Wear, Coming to a City Block Near You
description: Fashion’s reigning minimalists collaborate with Arc’teryx, the outerwear brand favored by hikers and hypebeasts.
content: It is a widely accepted truth that fashion has reached peak collaboration.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: What’s Going On in This Picture? | Nov. 8, 2021
description: Look closely at this image, stripped of its caption, and join the moderated conversation about what you and other students see.
content: 1. After looking closely at the image above (or at the full-size image), think about these three questions:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kevin Draper
title: Here’s how the Canelo Álvarez-Caleb Plant pay-per-view card played out.
description: Four fights in both the main card and in the prelims.
content: Here’s are the full results from the Álvarez-Plant card:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alanis Thames
title: Dolphins and Texans Swap Turnovers, if Not a Quarterback
description: The teams, both winless since Week 1 and connected by trade speculation surrounding Texans quarterback Deshaun Watson, combined for nine turnovers.
content: MIAMI GARDENS, Fla. — The first turnover came on the Houston Texans’ opening drive. Quarterback Tyrod Taylor, pressured by Miami Dolphins safety Brandon Jones, lofted the ball to the end zone, and it landed in the rookie Jevon Holland’s hands for an interception.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sophie Kasakove
title: With Cases Piling Up, an Eviction Crisis Unfolds Step by Step
description: Evictions are rising nationwide. “We don’t know where the ceiling is,” one expert said.
content: In Indianapolis, eviction courts are packed as judges make their way through a monthslong backlog of cases. In Detroit, advocates are rushing to knock on the doors of tenants facing possible eviction. In Gainesville, Fla., landlords are filing evictions at a rapid pace as displaced tenants resort to relatives’ couches for places to sleep or seek cheaper rents outside the city.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Kessler
title: The Week in Business: Time to Slow the Economic Stimulus
description: Jobs rebounded in October. The government finally issued rules on requiring vaccinations at big employers. And we'll see how quickly inflation is rising.
content: The Federal Reserve announced plans on Wednesday to slow its bond-buying program, a stimulus measure it introduced early in the pandemic. The central bank will reduce its monthly purchases of $120 billion in Treasury bonds and mortgage-backed securities by $15 billion a month, starting this month. The Fed’s policy committee did not give any indication it would raise interest rates anytime soon, despite persistently high inflation. But investors expect it will begin to do so midway through 2022.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Víctor Manuel Ramos
title: Two spotted hyenas at the Denver Zoo are the first known to have Covid-19.
description: The adult hyenas, who tested positive for the coronavirus, have so far exhibited mild symptoms of Covid, but they are believed to be “in good shape and improving,” a zoo spokesman said.
content: Two spotted hyenas at the Denver Zoo have tested positive for the coronavirus, becoming the first known cases in the world among hyenas, zoo and veterinary services officials announced on Friday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Norimitsu Onishi and Aurelien Breeden
title: French Clerical Abuse Report Puts Spotlight on Confession
description: In rare instances, it noted, the secrecy around the sacrament had been used to cover up abuse cases, again raising issues of whether church or state law should prevail.
content: PARIS — The absolute secrecy of confession is central to the Roman Catholic faith. What is said in confession is between a penitent and God, the priest a mediator. Any priest who breaks that seal can face excommunication under church laws that the Vatican places above all others.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annaliese Griffin
title: How to Buy Nothing New This Holiday Gifting Season
description: This is not about being a Grinch, canceling Christmas or trying to pass a minimalist purity test.
content: Every year my husband and I set a holiday challenge for each other: Find a gift at the local thrift store, something delightful that is a reflection of our individual aesthetics or obsessions. The tradition has brought some of my favorite objects into our home.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emmanuel Morgan
title: Justin Gaethje won a wild decision that was a surprise for even getting to the judges.
description: Gaethje could be in line for a title shot next.
content: The tangible excitement before, during and after the fight lived up to the product inside the cage. Justin Gaethje defeated Michael Chandler via unanimous decision in a lightweight bout to start the main card of U.F.C. 268, essentially earning a title shot for his next fight.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Giulia Heyward
title: Astroworld Victims Include High Schoolers and College Students
description: The music festival at Astroworld in Houston left eight people dead. Here is what is known about them so far.
content: Excitement and adrenaline soon turned to panic and horror as a crowd of 50,000 descended into chaos at the Astroworld music festival in Houston on Friday night. Unconscious bodies were lifted and surfed through the crowd, while other attendees begged for the concert to stop as they watched others around them collapse.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anton Troianovski
title: What’s in a Name? For the Koreans of Sakhalin, an Anguished History
description: Stranded for decades on the island in Russia’s Far East, some bear three names, Japanese, Russian and Korean, representing different historical chapters. Now, many are planning their return.
content: SAKHALIN ISLAND, Russia — On remote Sakhalin Island, near Russia’s eastern edge, tales of longing and splintered identity are embedded in people’s very names.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Laurel Graeber
title: An Indigenous Canadian Director Channels Traumatic Memories Into Film
description: Tracey Deer based “Beans” on her experiences as a child during the 1990 Oka crisis, a confrontation between the Mohawk people and the government.
content: Tracey Deer can still remember the sound of rocks hitting the car, her panicked mother’s orders to “Get down!” and the loud smash as a back passenger window shattered, showering glass over her screaming little sister.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Morgan Campbell
title: Pedigree wins out as Rey Vargas overcomes Leonardo Baez’s diligence.
description: A unanimous decision keeps Vargas undefeated.
content: The featherweights Rey Vargas and Leonardo Baez paced around the ring during prefight introductions decked out in identical Mexican flag serapes. For social media-savvy fight fans, the scene brought to mind the Spiderman-pointing-at-Spiderman meme.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chris Buckley
title: To Steer China’s Future, Xi Is Rewriting Its Past
description: A new official summation of Communist Party history is likely to exalt Xi Jinping as a peer of Mao and Deng, fortifying his claim to a new phase in power.
content: The glowing image of China’s top leader, Xi Jinping, greets visitors to museum exhibitions celebrating the country’s decades of growth. Communist Party biographers have worshipfully chronicled his rise, though he has given no hint of retiring. The party’s newest official history devotes over a quarter of its 531 pages to his nine years in power.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Vadukul
title: Stephen Karpiak, Pathbreaking H.I.V. Researcher, Dies at 74
description: His work helped change people’s attitude toward older people living with the virus that causes AIDS.
content: Stephen Karpiak, whose research into the lives of New Yorkers aging with H.I.V. revealed a scarcity of support networks and high rates of depression, leading to changes in the care of older people living with the virus, died on Oct. 16 at a hospital in Manhattan. He was 74.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kelly Kasulis Cho
title: On Tiny Guam, It’s One Dogcatcher vs. 30,000 Strays
description: They bite, they threaten, they carry the risk of rabies. Islanders are sharply divided over what to do about the dogs. And Nicholas Ibanez is caught in the middle.
content: MANGILAO, Guam — Driving alone in his truck, Nicholas Ibanez prowls the tiny American island of Guam in uniform, carrying a most-wanted list of dangerous predators that must be taken off the streets.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rachel Fabi
title: Get a Move On
description: Carl Larson gives solvers the royal treatment.
content: MONDAY PUZZLE — Welcome back to Carl Larson, who is making his third appearance in the New York Times Crossword. This Monday puzzle is sure to make you feel like royalty.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emmanuel Morgan
title: Kamaru Usman is still the 170-pound U.F.C. champion.
description: He beat Colby Covington in a decision carried by two knockdowns in the second round.
content: Kamaru Usman defended his welterweight championship, defeating his rival Colby Covington by unanimous decision.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emmanuel Morgan
title: Rose Namajunas keeps the 115-pound championship with a split decision over Zhang Weili.
description: The bout was close but Namajunas proved an effective counterpuncher.
content: Rose Namajunas defended her strawweight championship against Zhang Weili via split decision in a competitive fight, a rematch of their last fight that ended in a knockout.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Talya Minsberg
title: Running her first marathon, Abby Wambach plans to leave her teammates behind.
description: The former U.S. women’s soccer star was on the start line of the New York City Marathon with three of her former teammates.
content: Abby Wambach would really like to be done with running. At least that’s what she said before boarding a plane to run the New York City Marathon on Sunday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Yubelka Mendoza and Natalie Kitroeff
title: Nicaragua Descends Into Autocratic Rule as Ortega Crushes Dissent
description: President Daniel Ortega quashed the opposition and struck fear in voters, all but guaranteeing his victory in a presidential contest on Sunday.
content: MANAGUA, Nicaragua — Daniel Ortega became a hero in Nicaragua for helping overthrow a notorious dictator. Now, 40 years later, he has become the kind of authoritarian leader he once fought against.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Devin Gordon and Diante Lee
title: Playing It Safe, Giants Steal a Win From the Raiders
description: Are the Giants watchable yet? Not if you like offense.
content: Our N.F.L. playoffs calculator has an up-to-date look at the latest playoff picture.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Morgan Campbell
title: Canelo Álvarez delivered on his promise for a knockout victory.
description: He is the first man to unify boxing’s 168-pound belts.
content: LAS VEGAS — In the moments after Saúl Álvarez’s 11th-round knockout win over Caleb Plant, the sellout crowd at the MGM Grand Garden Arena rejoiced. The vast majority of the 16,586 spectators supported Álvarez, now the undisputed boxing world champion at 168 pounds.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jane Arraf
title: Fears of Wider Instability in Iraq After Attack on Prime Minister’s Home
description: Armed drones struck the Iraqi prime minister’s home in what was seen as a warning as Iranian-backed groups dispute the results of parliamentary elections.
content: Iraq’s prime minister survived a drone strike on his home early Sunday, Iraqi officials said, raising fears of wider instability after disputed results in Iraq’s parliamentary elections.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tish Harrison Warren
title: How Covid Raised the Stakes of the War Between Faith and Science
description: The debate isn’t just about creationism and stem cells anymore.
content: I have never had much interest in faith versus science debates. They simply did not resonate with me. I believe God created the world, but I never felt the need to nail down the details or method of creation. I went to a fairly conservative evangelical seminary (founded by Billy Graham himself), and even there, I was taught that Genesis 1 was more like a hymn or a poem than a science textbook. I have long been influenced by early church theologians like Augustine of Hippo, who understood the biblical creation account as primarily making theological claims instead of offering a precise explanation of cosmological origins.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Scott Cacciola
title: Albert Korir of Kenya wins the men’s race at the New York City Marathon.
description: It was a breakthrough performance for Korir, 27, who was the runner-up in New York in 2019.
content: Albert Korir of Kenya won the men’s race at the New York City Marathon on Sunday, finishing in 2 hours 8 minutes 22 seconds for his first major championship.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Morgan Campbell
title: Anthony Dirrell knocks out Marcos Hernandez with a windmill uppercut.
description: Dirrell said he hoped to face the winner of the main event in his next fight.
content: It’s tough to tell which Anthony Dirrell feat was more impressive.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard C. Paddock
title: Veteran U.S. Diplomat Comes Under Criticism for a Trip to Myanmar
description: Bill Richardson, a former ambassador to the U.N., said that he had held “productive” talks with the general who led the February coup. Rights activists said he gave the junta an air of legitimacy.
content: Bill Richardson, the American ex-diplomat, has made numerous trips to Myanmar since the 1990s. He has negotiated with the generals who ruled it, then and now. He has been an ally and later a critic of Daw Aung San Suu Kyi, its most popular politician, who is once again a prisoner of the army.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Sandomir
title: Michael Rutter, Pioneering Child Psychiatrist, Is Dead at 88
description: His wide-ranging research helped transform his field, a colleague said, by “insisting on using data to drive thinking about diagnosis and treatment.”
content: Dr. Michael Rutter, a British child psychiatrist whose many transformative studies included one that demonstrated the genetics of autism and another that assessed how poor treatment suffered by Romanian children in orphanages affected them after they were adopted by English families, died on Oct. 23 at his home in Dulwich, a suburb of London. He was 88.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Scott Cacciola
title: Peres Jepchirchir of Kenya wins the women’s race at the New York City Marathon.
description: Jepchirchir’s victory comes just three months after she won gold in the women’s marathon at the Tokyo Olympics.
content: In a dramatic finish to the women’s race at the New York City Marathon on Sunday, Peres Jepchirchir of Kenya pulled away in the final meters to win, just three months after she won gold in the women’s marathon at the Tokyo Olympics.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: In photos: The breathtaking view from above the New York City Marathon.
description: We sent photographers up in the air (in a helicopter and on a bridge) to capture the scope of the New York City Marathon from above.
content: We sent photographers Todd Heisler (in a helicopter) and Karsten Moran (on a bridge) up in the air to capture the scope of the New York City Marathon from above.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maya Phillips
title: Review: ‘Gnit’ Seeks Itself in a Mist of Magic and Mischief
description: Will Eno’s inward-looking incarnation of “Peer Gynt” steps out of Ibsen’s shadow just as Ibsen shrugged off elements of the original fairy tale.
content: We know the formula of the fairy tale: There is often a youth, sometimes a journey and always a touch of the fantastical to convey a moral or theme. Since we know the classic tropes from our childhood bedtime stories — don’t deviate from the path, be wary of witches, fear trolls — to contemporize a fairy tale is to shade these narrative standbys, coloring in the context of the time, updating the tone and plot to challenge our expectations.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Zucchino
title: Afghan Military Pilots, on the Run, Feel Abandoned by U.S.
description: Detained in Tajikistan, or hiding from the Taliban in Afghanistan, many pilots wonder why the military that trained them is not coming to their aid.
content: As Kabul was falling to the Taliban in August, the young Afghan Air Force pilot flew his PC-12 turboprop from Afghanistan to neighboring Tajikistan to escape. Like other Afghan officers who fled in dozens of military aircraft to Tajikistan and Uzbekistan, the pilot had faith that his American military partners would rescue him.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Morgan Campbell
title: Álvarez, Boxing’s Undisputed King, Is a Target for Fighters and Promoters
description: Would-be foes and matchmakers see the 168-pound champion as a path to a career payday.
content: LAS VEGAS — Saúl Álvarez’s team had the commemorative T-shirts ready. The fighter who goes by Canelo donned one moments after he had knocked out Caleb Plant to become the undisputed supermiddleweight boxing champion.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isaac Aronow and Doug Mennella
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: SUNDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeremy W. Peters
title: Republicans, Basking in Tuesday’s Victories, Diverge on What Comes Next
description: Looming over a gathering of Jewish conservatives in Las Vegas were questions about whether former President Donald J. Trump should remain the face of the party.
content: LAS VEGAS — Two strikingly divergent visions of Republican political strength played out over the weekend at a conference of Jewish conservatives, the first major gathering of G.O.P. leaders since the party’s sweeping success in Tuesday’s elections. There were displays of blustery confidence. And there were calls for caution and restraint as party leaders tried to process their drastic gains.
source.name: The New York Times

title: ‘A Woman Who Was Crossing the Street Yelled to the Man in the Hat’
description: A sidewalk exchange on the Lower East Side, a No. 6 mystery and more reader tales of New York City in this week’s Metropolitan Diary.
content: Dear Diary:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra Jacobs
title: ‘On Consolation’ Searches for Solace in the Face of Grief and Misery
description: In his new book, Michael Ignatieff says that we can find beauty and transcendence even when at our lowest depths.
content: Pharrell Williams sang about it. Tony Hsieh of Zappos promised to deliver it. Clinique named a perfume for it. Happiness has been the primary, bright-yellow pursuit of those living during what is now again modish to call, with disdain, “late capitalism,” as if the revolution were right around the corner, along with one’s Sweetgreen order. It’s the ultimate American oh-what-a-feeling, perpetually for sale and eternally elusive — and it’s been a bonanza for publishing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By C. J. Hughes
title: Homes That Sold for Around $450,000
description: Recent residential sales in New York City and the region.
content: Each week, our survey of recent residential sales in New York City and the surrounding region focuses on homes that sold around a certain price point, allowing you to compare single-family homes, condos and co-ops in different locales.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma G. Fitzsimmons and Katie Glueck
title: Who Wants to Hang Out With Eric Adams in Puerto Rico? Everyone.
description: Mr. Adams celebrated his victory in the New York City mayoral race with elected officials and lobbyists at a nonstop tropical party known as Somos.
content: SAN JUAN, P.R. — Three days after winning the New York City mayor’s race, Eric Adams arrived in Puerto Rico, a conquering hero basking in his element.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra E. Petri
title: Here’s how the celebrity runners fared in this year’s marathon.
description: Former U.S. women’s national soccer team members, musicians from Mumford and Sons, and a former first daughter are among some of the bold names running in the New York City Marathon.
content: For the first time since the onset of the pandemic, tens of thousands of runners hit the streets for the New York City Marathon, and celebrities and athletes once again raced alongside regular folks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Scott Cacciola
title: Emotion and Grit Power Kenyans in New York City Marathon
description: Albert Korir won the men’s division in 2:08:22, while Peres Jepchirchir won the women’s division in 2:22:39 after also winning at the Tokyo Games.
content: Viola Cheptoo was deep into the New York City Marathon on Sunday when she peered over her shoulder and made a plea to Peres Jepchirchir. The two Kenyans were leading the women’s race in a tight pack with Ababel Yeshaneh of Ethiopia, and Cheptoo desperately wanted to stay at the front for as long as possible.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabella Kwai
title: Britain’s health secretary urges people to get booster shots amid a surge.
description: “If we all come together and play our part, we can get through this challenging winter, avoid a return to restrictions and enjoy Christmas,” said Sajid Javid, the health secretary.
content: Britain’s health secretary is urging eligible residents to get booster shots of the coronavirus vaccine, aiming to reduce pressure on the country’s health system as winter approaches.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Helene Cooper and Eric Schmitt
title: Witnesses to the End
description: The young Marines in Kabul were left to determine who was evacuated from Afghanistan and who was left behind. The cost was high.
content: The Marines at Abbey Gate were racing against time. The crowd at the gate didn’t know it, but the Marines had been told to close it at 6 p.m.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: New York City Marathon Returns
description: Some 30,000 runners took on the 26.2-mile course through the city’s five boroughs, a year after the marathon was canceled because of the pandemic.
content: Some 30,000 runners took on the 26.2-mile course through the city’s five boroughs, a year after the marathon was canceled because of the pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: Nov. 7, 2021
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Sunday, Nov. 7, 2021.
content: Because of an editing error, an article last Sunday about the effect of supply-chain issues on the availability of Halloween costumes referred incorrectly to the history of the Salem witch trials. People suspected of witchcraft there were typically hanged, not burned or drowned.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Sifton
title: What to Cook This Week
description: With fall upon us in earnest, warm up with lamb meatballs and spiced tomato sauce.
content: Good morning. We picked up an hour of morning sun when Daylight Saving Time came to an end overnight in the United States, and now it’s autumn for real. Time to rake leaves and trim hedges, if you live that sort of life; to store your air-conditioner for the winter; to haul out your sweaters; to set up the Thanksgiving group chat to see who has a new dietary restriction or to determine who’s bringing what to dinner. (First time doing that? We’re here to help.) I’m setting up for 20-plus guests this year, if negative testing allows it. Marked on my to-do list for today: “Rent folding tables and chairs?”
source.name: The New York Times
